questions.text: A pharmaceutical developer is creating an educational tool for healthcare professionals about antibiotic options for non-clinical interventions. The focus is on preventing the transmission of infections in community settings. Which antibiotic should be highlighted as the primary option for eradicating Corynebacterium diphtheriae in asymptomatic carriers to curb the spread of diphtheria?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Erythromycin

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ Erythromycin is the drug of choice for the carrier state of diphtheria due to its effectiveness in eradicating Corynebacterium diphtheriae from carriers and preventing the spread of the disease. Other antibiotics like amoxicillin, rifampicin, and tetracycline are not considered first-line treatments for this condition.
  • ➤ Erythromycin is the drug of choice for the carrier state of diphtheria due to its effectiveness in eradicating Corynebacterium diphtheriae from carriers and preventing the spread of the disease.
  • ➤ Other antibiotics like amoxicillin, rifampicin, and tetracycline are not considered first-line treatments for this condition.

questions.text: A forensic expert is examining a victim of a fatal shooting during a criminal investigation. The entrance wound displays solely an abrasion collar. Based on these findings, what is the most likely firing distance of the firearm used in this incident?

  • ➤ Grease Collar (inner most) Abrasion collar Singeing Blackening Tattooing (outer most)
  • ➤ Grease Collar (inner most)
  • ➤ Abrasion collar
  • ➤ Singeing
  • ➤ Blackening
  • ➤ Tattooing (outer most)
  • ➤ Out of these five features, Abrasion collar and Grease collar can be found in any entry wound, irrespective of the distance between victim and firearm. This is because these are produced by bullet itself as it enters the body.
  • ➤ Abrasion collar and Grease collar
  • ➤ can be found in any entry wound, irrespective of the distance between victim and firearm.
  • ➤ Whereas Singeing, Blackening and Tattooing occur only upto a limited distance.
  • ➤ Singeing, Blackening and Tattooing occur only upto a limited distance.

questions.text: Which of the following is an example of a xenodiagnostic method?

questions.text: A 65-year-old male is brought to the emergency department in shock after trauma in an RTA. During resuscitation, the medical team intubates the patient. However, shortly after intubation, the capnograph is as depicted in the provided image. What is the most likely cause of this capnograph reading?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Esophageal intubation

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In cases of esophageal intubation, the capnograph typically shows a very low or absent end-tidal CO2 (EtCO2) reading with an almost flat waveform because the endotracheal tube is not in the trachea, leading to little to no CO2 being detected.
  • ➤ In cases of esophageal intubation, the capnograph typically shows a very low or absent end-tidal CO2 (EtCO2) reading with an almost flat waveform because the endotracheal tube is not in the trachea, leading to little to no CO2 being detected.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is incorrect regarding non-invasive prenatal testing (NIPT)?

options.label: A
options.text: It is used for the diagnosis of trisomy 13, 18, and 21

options.label: B
options.text: It uses cell-free circulating fetal DNA in the maternal serum

options.label: C
options.text: It is done after the routine first trimester ultrasound assessment

options.label: D
options.text: It can be performed after 10 weeks of gestation

questions.correct_answer: A. It is used for the diagnosis of trisomy 13, 18, and 21
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) It is used for the diagnosis of trisomy 13, 18, and 21

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:

questions.text: Match the E. coli pathotypes with their respective pathogenesis mechanisms. E. coli Pathotypes: ETEC (Enterotoxigenic E. coli) EIEC (Enteroinvasive E. coli) EHEC (Enterohemorrhagic E. coli) EPEC (Enteropathogenic E. coli) Mechanisms of Action: Produces a heat-stable toxin and causes activation of guanylate cyclase. Invades intestinal mucosal cells. Produces a toxin against endothelial cells. Adheres to the mucosal surface and causes effacement of microvilli.
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • A-1 : ETEC is correctly matched with "Produces a heat-stable toxin and causes activation of guanylate cyclase." This describes the mechanism by which ETEC causes watery diarrhea, typically seen in traveler’s diarrhea. B-2 : EIEC is matched with "Invades intestinal mucosal cells." This pathotype mirrors the pathogenic mechanism of Shigella, involving invasion and inflammation of the colon. C-3 : EHEC is known for producing Shiga toxin, which targets endothelial cells, leading to conditions like hemorrhagic colitis and hemolytic uremic syndrome. D-4 : EPEC’s primary pathogenic mechanism involves adhering to intestinal mucosa and effacing microvilli, leading to a characteristic attaching and effacing lesion.
  • • A-1 : ETEC is correctly matched with "Produces a heat-stable toxin and causes activation of guanylate cyclase." This describes the mechanism by which ETEC causes watery diarrhea, typically seen in traveler’s diarrhea.

  • • B-2 : EIEC is matched with "Invades intestinal mucosal cells." This pathotype mirrors the pathogenic mechanism of Shigella, involving invasion and inflammation of the colon.
  • • B-2
  • • C-3 : EHEC is known for producing Shiga toxin, which targets endothelial cells, leading to conditions like hemorrhagic colitis and hemolytic uremic syndrome.
  • • C-3
  • • D-4 : EPEC’s primary pathogenic mechanism involves adhering to intestinal mucosa and effacing microvilli, leading to a characteristic attaching and effacing lesion.
  • • D-4

questions.text: A histopathological examination of the retina from a patient presenting with visual changes as shown in the image provided. questions.text: A 11-year-old boy presents with a mildly painful, inflamed swelling on his scalp that has persisted for 4 months. He has a pet dog at home. The lesion, is shown in the image given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Kerion

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Kerion is a severe inflammatory reaction to a dermatophyte infection of the scalp, characterized by a boggy, inflamed area with hair loss. It often requires systemic antifungal treatment and may be associated with pet exposure.

questions.text: A 57-year-old male presents with complaints of epigastric pain, nausea, and significant weight loss over the past three months. On physical examination, peripheral edema is noted. questions.text: A physician is considering various treatment options for a patient with recurrent gout who experiences frequent acute inflammatory attacks. Which medication should the physician prescribe to specifically inhibit neutrophil recruitment, thereby reducing the inflammatory response in acute gout attacks?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Colchicine

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Colchicine is the drug that inhibits neutrophil recruitment by disrupting microtubules, thus affecting neutrophil mobility and reducing inflammation. This mechanism makes it effective in treating conditions like gout and familial Mediterranean fever.

questions.text: A gastroenterologist is reviewing different classes of medications for their prokinetic properties to treat a patient with gastroparesis. Which of the following drug classes does NOT exhibit prokinetic effects?

questions.text: In the emergency department, a 29-year-old man with known hypertension and stage 4 chronic kidney disease (eGFR <30 mL/min/1.73 m²) presents with signs of fluid overload. After initial stabilization, the attending physician evaluates diuretic options to manage his condition effectively given his renal impairment. Which diuretic would be most appropriate for this patient to achieve optimal fluid management without further compromising kidney function?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Metolazone

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Metolazone is the preferred thiazide-like diuretic for patients with stage 4 chronic kidney disease and an eGFR of less than 30 mL/min, as it retains its effectiveness even in the presence of significantly reduced kidney function. This is due to its additional action on the proximal tubule, which is less dependent on kidney function.
  • ➤ Metolazone is the preferred thiazide-like diuretic for patients with stage 4 chronic kidney disease and an eGFR of less than 30 mL/min, as it retains its effectiveness even in the presence of significantly reduced kidney function.
  • ➤ This is due to its additional action on the proximal tubule, which is less dependent on kidney function.

questions.text: A pregnant woman at 36 weeks of gestation presents with complaints of feeling light-headed and dizzy when lying on her back, which is relieved when she lies on her side or walks. What is the most likely reason behind this?

options.label: C
options.text: Excessive venous pooling at the feet

questions.explanation:
Ans. D) IVC compression

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Supine hypotensive syndrome, caused by IVC compression, leads to symptoms of dizziness and light-headedness when a pregnant woman lies on her back. These symptoms are relieved when she lies on her side, which alleviates the pressure on the IVC and improves venous return.
  • ➤ Supine hypotensive syndrome, caused by IVC compression, leads to symptoms of dizziness and light-headedness when a pregnant woman lies on her back.
  • ➤ These symptoms are relieved when she lies on her side, which alleviates the pressure on the IVC and improves venous return.
